paragraphs.text:
%md
# About
**Lab:** Sqoop to HDFS
**Objective:** Collect data from the RDBMS with Sqoop scripts. Store directly into Hive
**File locations:** Cloudair DB in PostgreSQL
**Successful outcome:** Collect data with Sqoop
**Before you begin:** Cloudair DB is in PostgreSQL
**Related lessons:** Sqoop in Action

---

msg.data:
About

Lab: Sqoop to HDFS
Objective: Collect data from the RDBMS with Sqoop scripts. Store directly into Hive
File locations: Cloudair DB in PostgreSQL
Successful outcome: Collect data with Sqoop
Before you begin: Cloudair DB is in PostgreSQL
Related lessons: Sqoop in Action
Setup

paragraphs.title: Ensure cloudair database is running in PostgreSQL
paragraphs.text:
%sh
export PGPASSWORD='BadPass%1'; psql -h db01.cloudair.lan -U devuser -d cloudair -p 5432  <<EOF
\dt
EOF

%md
#### **Important**
Sqoop will produce the message "Warning: /usr/hdp/3.1.5.0-152/accumulo does not exist! Accumulo imports will fail."
This message should be ignored in this environment because Accumulo is not installed.

msg.data:
Important

Sqoop will produce the message “Warning: /usr/hdp/3.1.5.0-152/accumulo does not exist! Accumulo imports will fail.”
This message should be ignored in this environment because Accumulo is not installed.
Lab
Create the Hive database

paragraphs.title: 1 - Create cloudair database

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Use Sqoop to import data into Hive table

msg.data: Use Sqoop to import data into Hive table

paragraphs.title: 2 - Scoop import into table eu_countries_stage with create table option
paragraphs.text:
%sh
sudo -u hdfs hdfs dfs -rm -r -skipTrash /data/cloudair/eu_country
rm /home/zeppelin/eu_country.java

sqoop import \
--connect jdbc:postgresql://db01.cloudair.lan:5432/cloudair \
--username devuser \
--password BadPass%1 \
--table eu_country \
--target-dir /data/cloudair/eu_country \
--fields-terminated-by "," \
--hive-import \
--hive-database cloudair \
--create-hive-table \
--hive-table eu_country_stage \
--num-mappers 1

%md
Defining the Sqoop options

~~~console
connect - Provides jdbc string
username - Database username
password - Alternatively you can use -password but this is not a good practice as its visible in your job execution logs 
           and asking for trouble. One way to deal with this is store database passwords in a file in HDFS and provide 
           at runtime. There is also a -P option to ask for the password from the CLI
table - Tells the computer which table you want to import from MySQL. Here, it is customer.
target-dir - HDFS destination directory.
fields-terminated-by - I have specified comma (as by default it will import data into HDFS with comma-separated values)
hive-import - Import table into Hive (Uses Hive default delimiters if none are set.)
hive-database - specify the hive database
create-hive-table - Determines if set job will fail if a Hive table already exists. It works in this case.
hive-table - Specifies <db_name>.<table_name>. Here it is sqoop_workspace.customers, where sqoop_workspace is my database and customers is the table name.
num-mappers - the number of mappers to use during the data transfer
~~~

num-mappers - the number of mappers to use during the data transfer

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Use Sqoop to overwrite data into Hive table

msg.data: Use Sqoop to overwrite data into Hive table

paragraphs.title: 7 - Create table sale_stage
paragraphs.text:
%jdbc(hive_interactive)
DROP TABLE IF EXISTS cloudair.sale_stage;

CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE cloudair.sale_stage(
    `entry_date` DATE,
    `item` STRING,
    `sales_code` INT,
    `cc_type` STRING,
    `first_name` STRING,
    `last_name` STRING,
    `city` STRING,
    `country_name` STRING,
    `purchase_date` DATE,
    `delivery_date` DATE,
    `purchase` DECIMAL(10,2),
    `credits` DECIMAL(10,2)
    )
ROW FORMAT DELIMITED 
FIELDS TERMINATED BY ','
STORED AS TEXTFILE
LOCATION '/data/cloudair/sale';

paragraphs.title: 8 - Sqoop import into existing table sale_stage with overwrite option
paragraphs.text:
%sh
sudo -u hdfs hdfs dfs -rm -r -skipTrash /data/cloudair/sale
rm /home/zeppelin/sale.java

sqoop import \
--connect jdbc:postgresql://db01.cloudair.lan:5432/cloudair \
--username devuser \
--password BadPass%1 \
--table sale \
--target-dir /data/cloudair/sale \
--fields-terminated-by "," \
--hive-import \
--hive-overwrite \
--hive-database cloudair \
--hive-table sale_stage \
--num-mappers 1

%md
Defining the Sqoop options

~~~console
connect - Provides jdbc string
username - Database username
password - Alternatively you can use -password but this is not a good practice as its visible in your job execution logs 
           and asking for trouble. One way to deal with this is store database passwords in a file in HDFS and provide 
           at runtime. There is also a -P option to ask for the password from the CLI
table - Tells the computer which table you want to import from MySQL. Here, it is customer.
target-dir - HDFS destination directory.
fields-terminated-by - I have specified comma (as by default it will import data into HDFS with comma-separated values)
hive-import - Import table into Hive (Uses Hive default delimiters if none are set.)
hive-overwrite - overwrites existing data in the Hive table.
hive-database - specify the hive database
hive-table - Specifies <db_name>.<table_name>. Here it is sqoop_workspace.customers, where sqoop_workspace is my database and customers is the table name.
num-mappers - the number of mappers to use during the data transfer
~~~

paragraphs.title: 10 - Create managed table sale as ORC format
paragraphs.text:
%jdbc(hive_interactive)
DROP TABLE IF EXISTS cloudair.sale;

CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE cloudair.sale(
    `entry_date` DATE,
    `item` STRING,
    `sales_code` INT,
    `cc_type` STRING,
    `first_name` STRING,
    `last_name` STRING,
    `city` STRING,
    `country_name` STRING,
    `purchase_date` DATE,
    `delivery_date` DATE,
    `purchase` DECIMAL(10,2),
    `credits` DECIMAL(10,2)
    )
COMMENT 'Cloudair Sales'
STORED AS ORC;

INSERT INTO cloudair.sale SELECT * FROM cloudair.sale_stage;

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Use Sqoop to ETL data into Hive table

msg.data: Use Sqoop to ETL data into Hive table

paragraphs.title: 13 - Create table us_customer_stage
paragraphs.text:
%jdbc(hive_interactive)
DROP TABLE IF EXISTS cloudair.us_customer_stage;

CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE cloudair.us_customer_stage(
    row_id STRING,
    title STRING,
    first_name STRING,
    middle_initial STRING,
    last_name STRING,
    name_set STRING,
    street_address STRING,
    city STRING,
    state STRING,
    state_name STRING,
    zip_code INT,
    country_id STRING,
    country_name STRING,
    telephone_country_code STRING,
    telephone_number STRING,
    email_address STRING,
    username STRING,
    password STRING,
    national_id STRING,
    mrn INT,
    insurance_id INT,
    cc_type STRING,
    cc_number STRING,
    cvv2 INT,
    cc_expires DATE,
    occupation STRING,
    company STRING,
    domain STRING,
    vehicle STRING,
    gender STRING,
    mothers_maiden STRING,
    birthday DATE,
    tropical_zodiac STRING,
    age INT,
    eye_color STRING,
    blood_type STRING,
    weight DOUBLE,
    height INT,
    latitude DOUBLE,
    longitude DOUBLE
    )
ROW FORMAT DELIMITED FIELDS 
TERMINATED BY ',' ESCAPED BY '"'
STORED AS TEXTFILE
LOCATION '/data/cloudair/us_customer'
tblproperties("skip.header.line.count"="1");

paragraphs.title: 14 - Sqoop import into existing table us_customer_stage with hive drop import delims
paragraphs.text:
%sh
sudo -u hdfs hdfs dfs -rm -r -skipTrash /data/cloudair/us_customer
rm /home/zeppelin/us_customer.java

sqoop import \
--connect jdbc:postgresql://db01.cloudair.lan:5432/cloudair \
--username devuser \
--password BadPass%1 \
--table us_customer \
--columns row_number,title,first_name,middle_initial,last_name,street_address,city,state,zip_code \
--target-dir /data/cloudair/us_customer \
--fields-terminated-by "," \
--hive-import \
--hive-database cloudair \
--hive-table us_customer_stage \
--hive-drop-import-delims --null-string '\\N' --null-non-string '\\N' \
--num-mappers 1

%md
Defining the Sqoop options

~~~console
connect - Provides jdbc string
username - Database username
password - Alternatively you can use -password but this is not a good practice as its visible in your job execution logs 
           and asking for trouble. One way to deal with this is store database passwords in a file in HDFS and provide 
           at runtime. There is also a -P option to ask for the password from the CLI
table - Tells the computer which table you want to import from MySQL. Here, it is customer.
columns - Specifies the columns to pull from the DB table.
target-dir - HDFS destination directory.
fields-terminated-by - I have specified comma (as by default it will import data into HDFS with comma-separated values)
hive-import - Import table into Hive (Uses Hive default delimiters if none are set.)
hive-overwrite - overwrites existing data in the Hive table.
hive-database - specify the hive database
hive-table - Specifies <db_name>.<table_name>. Here it is sqoop_workspace.customers, where sqoop_workspace is my database and customers is the table name.
hive-drop-import-delims - Drops the delimiters \n, \r, and \01 from string fields when importing data into Hive.
num-mappers - the number of mappers to use during the data transfer
~~~

msg.data:
Defining the Sqoop options

connect - Provides jdbc string
username - Database username
password - Alternatively you can use -password but this is not a good practice as its visible in your job execution logs 
           and asking for trouble. One way to deal with this is store database passwords in a file in HDFS and provide 
           at runtime. There is also a -P option to ask for the password from the CLI
table - Tells the computer which table you want to import from MySQL. Here, it is customer.
columns - Specifies the columns to pull from the DB table.
target-dir - HDFS destination directory.
fields-terminated-by - I have specified comma (as by default it will import data into HDFS with comma-separated values)
hive-import - Import table into Hive (Uses Hive default delimiters if none are set.)
hive-overwrite - overwrites existing data in the Hive table.
hive-database - specify the hive database
hive-table - Specifies <db_name>.<table_name>. Here it is sqoop_workspace.customers, where sqoop_workspace is my database and customers is the table name.
hive-drop-import-delims - Drops the delimiters \n, \r, and \01 from string fields when importing data into Hive.
num-mappers - the number of mappers to use during the data transfer

DROP TABLE IF EXISTS cloudair.us_customer;

    row_id STRING,
    title STRING,
    first_name STRING,
    middle_initial STRING,
    last_name STRING,
    name_set STRING,
    street_address STRING,
    city STRING,
    state STRING,
    state_name STRING,
    zip_code INT,
    country_id STRING,
    country_name STRING,
    telephone_country_code STRING,
    telephone_number STRING,
    email_address STRING,
    username STRING,
    password STRING,
    national_id STRING,
    mrn INT,
    insurance_id INT,
    cc_type STRING,
    cc_number STRING,
    cvv2 INT,
    cc_expires DATE,
    occupation STRING,
    company STRING,
    domain STRING,
    vehicle STRING,
    gender STRING,
    mothers_maiden STRING,
    birthday DATE,
    tropical_zodiac STRING,
    age INT,
    eye_color STRING,
    blood_type STRING,
    weight DOUBLE,
    height INT,
    latitude DOUBLE,
    longitude DOUBLE
    )
STORED AS ORC;

paragraphs.title: 19 - Create table ww_customer_stage
paragraphs.text:
%jdbc(hive_interactive)
DROP TABLE IF EXISTS cloudair.ww_customer_stage;

CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE cloudair.ww_customer_stage(
    row_id STRING,
    title STRING,
    first_name STRING,
    middle_initial STRING,
    last_name STRING,
    name_set STRING,
    street_address STRING,
    city STRING,
    state_code STRING,
    state_name STRING,
    zip_code INT,
    country_code STRING,
    country_name STRING,
    telephone_country_code STRING,
    telephone_number STRING,
    email_address STRING,
    username STRING,
    password STRING,
    national_id STRING,
    mrn INT,
    insurance_id INT,
    cc_type STRING,
    cc_number STRING,
    cvv2 INT,
    cc_expires DATE,
    occupation STRING,
    company STRING,
    domain STRING,
    vehicle STRING,
    gender STRING,
    mothers_maiden STRING,
    birthday DATE,
    tropical_zodiac STRING,
    age INT,
    eye_color STRING,
    blood_type STRING,
    weight DOUBLE,
    height INT,
    latitude DOUBLE,
    longitude DOUBLE
    )
ROW FORMAT DELIMITED 
FIELDS TERMINATED BY ',' 
ESCAPED BY '"'
STORED AS TEXTFILE
LOCATION '/data/cloudair/ww_customer'
tblproperties("skip.header.line.count"="1");

paragraphs.title: 20 - Scoop import into existing table ww_customer_stage
paragraphs.text:
%sh
sudo -u hdfs hdfs dfs -rm -r -skipTrash /data/cloudair/ww_customer
rm /home/zeppelin/ww_customer.java

sqoop import \
--connect jdbc:postgresql://db01.cloudair.lan:5432/cloudair \
--username devuser \
--password BadPass%1 \
--split-by row_number \
--table us_customer \
--target-dir /data/cloudair/ww_customer \
--fields-terminated-by "," \
--hive-import \
--hive-database cloudair \
--hive-table ww_customer_stage \
--hive-drop-import-delims --null-string '\\N' --null-non-string '\\N' \
--num-mappers 4

%md
Defining the Sqoop options

~~~console
connect - Provides jdbc string
username - Database username
password - Alternatively you can use -password but this is not a good practice as its visible in your job execution logs 
           and asking for trouble. One way to deal with this is store database passwords in a file in HDFS and provide 
           at runtime. There is also a -P option to ask for the password from the CL
split-by - Specifies the colunn to use for splitting between the mappers.
table - Tells the computer which table you want to import from MySQL. Here, it is customer.
target-dir - HDFS destination directory.
fields-terminated-by - I have specified comma (as by default it will import data into HDFS with comma-separated values)
hive-import - Import table into Hive (Uses Hive default delimiters if none are set.)
hive-overwrite - overwrites existing data in the Hive table.
hive-database - specify the hive database
hive-table - Specifies <db_name>.<table_name>. Here it is sqoop_workspace.customers, where sqoop_workspace is my database and customers is the table name.
hive-drop-import-delims - Drops the delimiters \n, \r, and \01 from string fields when importing data into Hive.
num-mappers - the number of mappers to use during the data transfer
~~~

hive-import - Import table into Hive (Uses Hive default delimiters if none are set.)
hive-overwrite - overwrites existing data in the Hive table.
hive-database - specify the hive database
hive-table - Specifies <db_name>.<table_name>. Here it is sqoop_workspace.customers, where sqoop_workspace is my database and customers is the table name.

paragraphs.title: 30 - Drop staging tables
Drop Hive DB
paragraphs.text:
%jdbc(hive_interactive)
DROP DATABASE IF EXISTS cloudair CASCADE;

%sh
# Delete data/cloudair in HDFS
sudo -u hdfs hdfs dfs -rm -r -skipTrash /data/cloudair

# Ensure cloudair database is running in PostgreSQL
export PGPASSWORD='BadPass%1'; psql -h db01.cloudair.lan -U devuser -d cloudair -p 5432  <<EOF
\dt
